title: Jehangir Sabavala
summary: Jehangir Sabavala (1922-2011) was a prominent Indian painter born into an affluent Parsi family in Mumbai. He received extensive art education, first at Mumbai's Sir J. J. School of Art, then in London (Heatherley School of Fine Art) and Paris (Academie Andre Lhote, Académie Julian, Académie de la Grande Chaumière). From 1951, Sabavala held 31 major solo exhibitions and participated in over 150 group exhibitions worldwide. His works are held in significant public and private collections, including the National Gallery of Modern Art. Sabavala's life and art were the subjects of two films, 'Colours of Absence' (1994 National Award winner) and 'The Inheritance of Light' (2010). His paintings achieved high prices at auctions, and he was honored with the Padma Shri (1977) and the Lalit Kala Ratna (2007).

timeline: 1922: Born Jehangir Ardeshir Sabavala in Bombay (Mumbai).
1944: Earned a diploma from Mumbai's Sir J. J. School of Art.
1945-1947: Studied at the Heatherley School of Fine Art, London.
1948-1951: Studied at Academie Andre Lhote, Paris.
1953-1954: Studied at the Académie Julian, Paris.
1957: Studied at the Académie de la Grande Chaumière.
1977: Awarded the Padma Shri by the Government of India.
1994: Arun Khopkar's film 'Colours of Absence' on his life and art won the National Award.
2007: Awarded the Lalit Kala Ratna, the Fellowship of Lalit Kala Akademi.
2008: Held his last solo exhibition, 'Ricorso', at Sakshi Gallery, Mumbai.
2010: Film 'The Inheritance of Light: Jehangir Sabavala' was made about his life.
2010: His painting 'Casuarina Line' fetched Rs 17 million at a Saffronart auction.

current_status: Jehangir Sabavala passed away in 2011, but his legacy as a prominent Indian painter continues. His works remain highly valued in the art market and are preserved in significant public and private collections globally. Films and books about his life and art ensure his artistic contributions are recognized and studied, maintaining his enduring presence in Indian art history.
future_prospects: Future prospects include continued appreciation and academic study of his extensive body of work. There is potential for further growth in the market value of his paintings. His legacy may inspire new exhibitions, retrospectives, or scholarly publications exploring his influence on modern Indian art. His works are likely to remain central to discussions of 20th and early 21st-century Indian painting.
